## Back to the toolbox

![](img/toolkit.png){fig-align="center"}

## Check your variables

```{r}
#| label: load penguins
#| include: true
#| echo: true

library(palmerpenguins)
library(tidyverse)

penguins %>% 
  glimpse()

```

## Is there an association between "Species" and "Sex"?

```{r}
#| label: cat_cat_graph
#| include: true
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column
penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x= species, 
    color=sex, 
    fill=sex))+
  geom_bar(position = "dodge")-> cat_x_cat
cat_x_cat
```

## How species differ in bill length?


```{r}
#| label: cat_num_graph
#| include: true
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column
penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x= species, 
    y= bill_length_mm,
    color=species, 
    fill=species))+
  geom_boxplot(alpha=0.7)-> cat_x_num

cat_x_num
```

## What is the relationship between bill leght and flipper lenght?


```{r}
#| label: num_num_graph
#| include: true
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column
penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x= bill_length_mm, 
    y= flipper_length_mm,
    color=species))+
  geom_point()-> num_x_num

num_x_num
```

## Can body mass predict sex?


```{r}
#| label: num_cat_graph
#| include: true
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column
penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x= body_mass_g, 
    y= sex,
    color=species))+
  geom_point()-> num_x_cat

num_x_cat
```


## The four families of statistical tests

```{r}
#| label: all graphs

library(cowplot)

plot_grid(cat_x_cat,num_x_cat, cat_x_num,num_x_num)


```

## Frequency tests

:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

```{r}
#| label: freq test
#| 
cat_x_cat
```

:::

:::{.column width="50%"}

- Chi-square
- G-tests
- Contingecy tables
- Log-linear models

:::
:::

:::{.fragment}
Powerful for testing associations between categorical variables
:::

## Mean tests
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

```{r}
#| label: mean test
#| 
cat_x_num
```

:::

:::{.column width="50%"}

- T-tests (two levels)
- Anovas (3+ levels)
- Non-parametric equivalents
- Nested and two-way...
- Post-hoc tests (Tukey HSD, Student, etc.)

:::
:::

:::{.fragment}
Widely used for testing differences in means
:::
